criteria.name: Market Share
criteria.description: The percentage of total sales within the health care supplies industry that a company controls.
criteria.reason: Market share is crucial for assessing a company's competitive position and growth potential.
examples: Company A holds 15% of the market share in surgical supplies.
Company B dominates 30% of the wound care market.

data_points.name: Total Sales of Company
data_points.description: Total sales revenue of the company in the health care supplies segment.

data_points.name: Total Market Size
data_points.description: Overall revenue generated by all companies in the health care supplies industry.

normalized_data_points.name: Market Share Percentage
normalized_data_points.formula: (Total Sales of Company / Total Market Size) * 100

key_points: Identify leading companies in terms of market control.
Evaluate changes in market share over time.
Consider barriers to entry for new competitors.
Assess the impact of mergers and acquisitions.

charts.usage: To visually represent the distribution of market shares among different companies in the health care supplies sector.
To track changes in market share over time, illustrating the growth or decline of specific companies.

criteria.name: Cost Efficiency
criteria.description: Measures how effectively a company manages its costs relative to its revenue.
criteria.reason: Cost efficiency affects profitability and competitiveness in pricing.
examples: Company A's cost per unit is lower than the industry average.
Company B has optimized its supply chain, reducing logistics costs.

data_points.name: Cost of Goods Sold (COGS)
data_points.description: Total direct costs attributable to the production of goods sold by a company.

data_points.name: Revenue
data_points.description: Total sales revenue of the company within the health care supplies market.

normalized_data_points.name: COGS as a Percentage of Revenue

key_points: Analyze cost structures against industry standards.
Monitor cost trends in raw materials.

charts.usage: To compare cost efficiency ratios across different companies in the industry.
To show the breakdown of costs over time, illustrating changes in cost components.

criteria.name: Regulatory Compliance
criteria.description: The adherence to laws and regulations governing the health care supplies industry.
criteria.reason: Compliance is crucial for legal operations and avoids penalties.
examples: Company A undergoes routine audits and maintains certifications.
Company B has had compliance issues resulting in sanctions.

data_points.name: Number of Regulatory Violations
data_points.description: Instances of non-compliance recorded within a set period.

data_points.name: Audit Findings
data_points.description: Outcomes of internal and external compliance audits.

charts.usage: To display the number of regulatory violations by company, making it easy to spot patterns.
To visualize compliance rates across different departments or regions.

criteria.name: Innovation and R&D Investment
criteria.description: Evaluation of the company’s investment in research and development for new products and technologies.
criteria.reason: Innovation is key to staying competitive in a rapidly advancing field.
examples: Company A increased its R&D budget by 20% this year.
Company B launched 5 new products in the last year.

data_points.name: R&D Expenditure
data_points.description: Amount spent on research and development activities.

data_points.name: Number of New Products Launched
data_points.description: Total new products introduced by the company in a year.

key_points: Assess the alignment of R&D with market needs.
Evaluate outcomes of past R&D investments.
Monitor patent filings and intellectual property.

charts.usage: To compare the innovation indices of various companies visually.
To demonstrate the correlation between R&D investment and revenue growth over several years.

criteria.name: Supply Chain Robustness
criteria.description: Measures the strength and reliability of a company's supply chain structure.
criteria.reason: A resilient supply chain ensures consistent product availability.
examples: Company A has multiple suppliers for critical materials.
Company B faced significant delays causing stockouts.

data_points.name: Lead Time
data_points.description: Average time from order placement to delivery.

data_points.name: Number of Suppliers
data_points.description: Total suppliers used for key materials.

key_points: Engage suppliers in performance improvement initiatives.

charts.usage: To visualize the relationship between lead times and number of suppliers.
To show the supply chain process and identify areas of potential delay.

criteria.name: Customer Satisfaction
criteria.description: Measure of how products and services meet or exceed customer expectations.
criteria.reason: High customer satisfaction correlates with repeat business and brand loyalty.
examples: Company A receives high ratings on customer feedback surveys.
Company B struggles with negative reviews regarding product quality.

data_points.name: Customer Satisfaction Score (CSAT)
data_points.description: Assessment of customer satisfaction based on survey responses.

data_points.name: Net Promoter Score (NPS)
data_points.description: Metric for customer loyalty and likelihood to recommend.

key_points: Conduct regular surveys to gather feedback.
Monitor social media for customer sentiments.

charts.usage: To represent the level of customer satisfaction compared to benchmarks.
To analyze satisfaction trends over time.

criteria.name: Sales Growth
criteria.description: The rate at which a company’s sales revenue is increasing over a specific period.
criteria.reason: Sales growth indicates overall company health and market demand.
examples: Company A reports a 15% year-over-year sales growth.
Company B is experiencing declining sales due to increased competition.

data_points.name: Annual Sales Growth Rate
data_points.description: Percentage increase in sales compared to the previous year.

data_points.name: Market Growth Rate
data_points.description: Growth of the overall health care supplies market.

normalized_data_points.name: Sales Growth Percentage
normalized_data_points.formula: ((Current Year Sales - Previous Year Sales) / Previous Year Sales) * 100

key_points: Track quarterly sales data for trends.
Consider macroeconomic factors influencing the industry.

charts.usage: To compare sales growth rates among different companies.
To depict the trend of sales growth over time.

criteria.name: Quality Control
criteria.description: The processes in place to ensure product quality and reduce defects.
criteria.reason: Maintaining high-quality standards is essential for customer trust and regulatory compliance.
examples: Company A utilizes stringent testing procedures before product releases.
Company B recalled products due to quality issues.

data_points.name: Defect Rate
data_points.description: Percentage of products failing quality tests.

data_points.name: Return Rate
data_points.description: Percentage of products returned due to quality issues.

key_points: Track historical defect and return rates.
Educate staff on quality standards and practices.

charts.usage: To show the distribution of defect rates across product lines.
To visualize the variability and identify outliers in quality control metrics.
